Posts.Title: Angry over sick note

Posts.Content: Hi, glad it has come round at last for you, it is one of my wife's least favourite scans and she had had a few so it is doable.. There is quite a good write up on it on the cancer research uk site. The data does take a bit of a while to process and to be interpreted, do you know when they expect to give you the results - will it be just before the operation? As to when you should take the Valium is an hour before what your GP advised, from a quick scan on the net that seems to be fairly normal. The only time I have had it was just before I had an angigram. Do talk to the medics at the MRI, they are used to people having issues and are expert in helping people cope. <<hugs>> Steve
Posts.Title: MRI tomorrow! Any advice?

Posts.Content: I understand your concerns, watched my wife get sicker and sicker with something that does not sound so disimilar and bounced from pillar to post with gynae saying it must be somewhere else had huge numbers of tests the found stuff in her lungs, they thought it must be the bowel looked absolutly everywhere - except the womb, gynae said I see women like this all the time ignoring the fact it was different for her. After she collapsed and had an emergency hysterectomy he eventually diagnosed pyometra - common in dogs, rare in people. It all but killed her - but it is not cancer. She has a fairly hazy memory of all this since she was being so badly poisoned, I on the other hand saw it sooo clearly - is there anyone supporting you? What you have is something, it sound like it could be quite serious and you are getting it checked out - absolutly fantastic. It might be cancer is might not, whatever it is you are dealing with it as best you can and at least with the suspicion it might be cancer you get an urgent appointment. One quote I quite like is “Worrying does not take away tomorrow’s troubles. It takes away today’s peace.” Hope the appointment comes through soon and whatever path you need to walk in the future becomes more clear. <<hugs>> Steve
Posts.Title: I just don't know what to do or think??????

Posts.Content: Sorry nobody repliced earlier, dont have any expereince with AC but my wife had the "A" on its own for a different cancer altogher. She did not bother with cold cap because it would have nearly doubled the length of time her treatment would take. There is a whole page of information on AC on the main site. When she started to lose her hair she had it cut short and ended up losing all the hair on her head and went for a scaft or just bald and proud. After the chemo her hair grew back quite quickly and with a bit of a curl that she quite liked but not it has returned to "normality". Hope you get some more direct answers about the AC treament - one thing my wife missed was that the "A" makes your pee red - quite alarming if you are not expecting it. <<hugs>> Steve
Posts.Title: Penguin Cold cap

Posts.Content: A PET-CT is a combination of a PET scan where they inject a tracer into you and see where it goes and a CT scan. Takes quite a bit longer because they have to let the tracer do its work before they can scan you. Info on PET scans can be found here. Other than the injection and the extra time waiing it is not very different to a CT scan. <<hugs>> Steve

Posts.Title: Delaying radiotherapy for a few weeks - could it be detrimental?

Posts.Content: All a CT scan will show is something different, for my wife they found something different in her lung and assumed it was lung cancer, turns out if was just some odd form of webbing/scar tissue and it was containing quite a lot of infection. Being referred "urgently" just means there is some potential that it could be cancer and it is important to rule that out, it is standard to mark potential cancer issues as "urgent". You might be interested for the information from the main site on "being diagnosed with breast cancer" The good news of course is is it is breast cancer it will have been caught very early. Hope they work out what is happening elsewhere too as it sounds like you have been suffering quite badly. <<hugs>> Steve
Posts.Title: Can a ct scan pick up breast cancer

Posts.Content: I can really relate, one of the issues around cancer is that people think cancer is a either cured or your dead. Seen cases on here where that sort of rubbish has even come from doctors. Well Janice has every intention of going on for a great many years yet, my personal bet is she is far more likely to die in a road accident (probably my driving). She is among one of the most thoroughly scanned, checked, documented, probed, prodded, people in the country, if anything were to show up I am sure they would be on top of it. For most of us of course we simply don't know and it is often said ignorance is bliss. She got her appointment yesterday for her next meeting with the oncologist, 24th February and a sensible time too, so that's bound to move, a day after my appointment with the rheumatologist. Still at least they are still talking, the number who cannot find anything to say so shy away. Have a really great Christmas, and next Christmas, and next..... We are fairly safe round here, all the bus services have been cut. <<hugs>> Steve

Posts.Title: Am I missing something???

Posts.Content: While it is truth in what we eat affects our chances of getting cancer there are also highly dedicated vegans who still get cancer. I would argue look at all the facts and make your own mind up. I just like many others say dont just jump on board with what is offered. Be very careful to read all the facts not just the cure rates but that it will almost certainly make you ill in the short term, it might not make you any better, it might make things worse or even shorten your life. I am entirely pro-choice. However I am not pro "chemo is bad" for that because all the evidence says that it helps many more people than it harms otherwise the doctors would not recommend it, it would not be ethical. Are there better treatments out there, almost certainly but at the end of the day someone has to pay the bills, be grateful for the NHS that it is not you and you are not faced by the dilema of is the doctor just recomming this because it has been a bit of a slow month. Steve
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Well just to be fair, because I am nothing but, I will share information about eating processed and red meats. Of course there is next to nothing like a fact in the real world, it is all shades of grey. It is very important to listen carefully to your oncologist but to also ask questions say can you show me why you say that, look at all the risks and make your own mind up. If you consider doing complementary medecine (ie something alongside conventional) then talk to your oncologist because sometimes there can be interactions but if it does no harm I have yet to find one who would stop you, since they cannot, but perhaps don't expect them to be overflowing with support. You might consider doing nothing, in fact for some slow growing cancers that are not actually causing any problems that is often the best thing but often people plea for treatment. The trouble with your rebutal of my comment is simple I said take 1000 vegans and some of them will get cancer - most of them won't. Take 1000 meat eaters and some of them will get cancer, a few more than the vegan group. Your answer is 1 person did not get cancer. Any decision made by a cancer sufferer show courage, to go for treatment, to not go for treatment, whatever and for them whatever decision and however they made it is the right one. The one fact in life is at the end we all die, so on that cheery note I wish you farewell. Steve
